title: Inquiry Process for Exploring Mathematical Logic and Reasoning Structures Applying Dialectical Constructivism

context.prior_knowledge: Basic mathematical concepts (set theory, propositional logic) and intermediate-level algebra/analysis application skills, experience with logical reasoning and proof construction
context.additional_context: Cultivating critical analysis of abstract mathematical concepts (axioms, theorems, proofs) by applying dialectical constructivist pedagogy. Particularly focuses on exploring relationships between formal logic systems and informal reasoning.

learning_goals: Learners analyze mathematical propositions and equations in a dialectical (pro-con) structure to identify and argue against logical fallacies.

Learners systematically construct three mathematical logic debates using the six elements of the Toulmin argumentation model (claim-grounds-warrant-rebuttal-qualifier-booster) on a graduate discussion platform and submit argumentative essays that meet at least four of the five evaluation criteria (clarity, logicality, sufficiency of evidence, rebuttal response, structural completeness) based on peer reviews and instructor feedback.

Learners incorporate at least three peer feedbacks, correct at least two logical fallacies (e.g., circular reasoning, straw man fallacy) in mathematical arguments, and submit a self-reflection report with added graphs/statistical data within two weeks.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
